Description: THE NATIONAL OCEAN SCIENCES BOWL (NOSB) IS A VITAL EDUCATION PROGRAM AND ACADEMIC COMPETITION THAT HAS PLAYED A CRUCIAL ROLE IN PROMOTING OCEAN LITERACY AND INSPIRING THE NEXT GENERATION OF OCEAN SCIENTISTS FOR THE PAST 25 YEARS. THE NOSB HAS PROVIDED A PLATFORM FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN ABOUT OCEAN SCIENCE AND THE WEALTH OF OCEAN SCIENCE-RELATED CAREERS. STUDENTS GAIN SKILLS TO BECOME FUTURE LEADERS IN THE FIELD, CONTRIBUTING TO NOAA'S EFFORTS TO PROMOTE OCEAN LITERACY, ENHANCE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF OCEAN ISSUES, AND FOSTER THE NEXT GENERATION OF SCIENTISTS AND KNOWLEDGEABLE CITIZENS. THE NOSB HAS OPERATED FOR 25 YEARS IN ITS CURRENT QUIZ BOWL FORMAT WITHOUT MAJOR CHANGES. IN THAT TIME, EDUCATION AND OCEAN LITERACY NEEDS HAVE EVOLVED AND THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAD MYRIAD IMPACTS ON STUDENTS AND EDUCATION. THE NOSB PROGRAM ALSO RECENTLY TRANSFERRED TO THE CENTER FOR OCEAN LEADERSHIP (COL) AT THE UNIVERSITY CORPORATION OF ATMOSPHERIC RESEARCH (UCAR). GIVEN THESE FACTORS, IT IS A BENEFICIAL TIM
SINGLE AUIDT REPORT ATTACHED TO GOL SECTION. HAD NO FINDINGS REPORTED IN FY22

SINGLE AUDIT REPORT ATTACHED TO SINGLE AUDIT SECTION

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE WAREHAM (MA) PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO AFFECT POSITIVE CHANGE IN THEIR COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING A DISTRICT-WIDE PROGRAM WHERE STUDENTS WILL LEARN ABOUT HOW SHELLFISH PROVIDE A NATURAL SOLUTION TO CLIMATE-CHANGE AND NITROGEN POLLUTION IN THEIR WATERSHED THROUGH TEACHER-IMPLEMENTED OUTDOOR EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES. THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ALONG WITH STUDENT AND TEACHER LEARNING ENRICHMENT TO CREATE MEANINGFUL CONNECTION TO LOCAL NATURAL PLACES WHILE ALSO PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO ENGAGE WITH BLUE ECONOMIES IN THEIR COMMUNITY. THIS PROJECT EXPECTS TO REACH 620 STUDENTS IN 6TH AND 7TH GRADE AND ENGAGE 20 TEACHERS.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT WATERSHED-BASED EDUCATION IN THE CONNECTICUT RIVER VALLEY, FOCUSING ON RURAL UNDERSERVED SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN WESTERN MASSACHUSETTS. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE LONG-TERM ENGAGEMENT OF STUDENTS IN CLASSROOM AND FIELD BASED LEARNING AS WELL AS PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT SUPPORT FOR TEACHERS. THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE STUDENTS IN COMMUNITY-BASED ACTION, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT LEARNING, AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCE ENGINEERING DESIGN CHALLENGES THAT DRAW FROM NOAA'S CLIMATE EDUCATION TOOLKIT. THIS PROJECT WILL REACH APPROXIMATELY 200 STUDENTS, 10 TEACHERS, 5 PRINCIPALS 1 CURRICULUM DIRECTOR, 20 PARENT CHAPERONES, AND 6 REGIONAL/TOWN PLANNING OR CLIMATE RESILIENCE EXPERTS.

MAINE AUDUBON WILL FOCUS ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND CULTURAL LANDSCAPES OF THE PENOBSCOT RIVER WATERSHED, NEW ENGLAND'S SECOND LARGEST RIVER SYSTEM AND HOME TO THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON AND IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR SOME TEN OTHER MIGRATORY FISH SPECIES. MAINE AUDUBON AND PARTNERS WILL PROVIDE JOB-EMBEDDED TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR FOURTEEN 5TH GRADE TEACHERS THROUGH FIELD EXPERIENCES, FIELD TRAINING INSTITUTES, AND ASYNCHRONOUS LEARNING MODULES THAT ARE INTEGRATED WITHIN THEIR TEACHING PRACTICE. STUDENTS FROM THE ENTIRE BANGOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS 5TH GRADE CLASS (280 STUDENTS) WILL ENGAGE IN MULTIPLE OUTDOOR FIELD EXPERIENCES.

THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND CAPACITY FOR SEABROOK (NH) MIDDLE SCHOOL TO EXPAND ON A PREVIOUS B-WET AWARD (NOAA # NA19NMF0080090) IN AREAS OF ONGOING FIELD SUPPORT AND TRANSFERABILITY, CONTENT FOCUS (SHIFT FROM EELS TO SALTMARSH HABITATS AND CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS), AND CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT APPROACH. THIS PROJECT WILL BRING TOGETHER A COLLABORATIVE OF MIDDLE SCHOOL TEACHERS AND ADMINISTRATORS, VOLUNTEER EDUCATORS, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, AND NH SEA GRANT FACULTY AND STAFF TO WORK TOGETHER TO INCREASE STUDENT KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND COMPETENCIES RELATED TO NEW HAMPSHIRE SALT MARSHES TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS AND IDENTIFY SOLUTIONS TOWARD MARSH RESILIENCE. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPERIMENT WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A TEAM OF FIELD DOCENTS TO ASSIST TEACHERS WITH OUTDOOR SALT MARSH EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FACILITATE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABLE CURRICULUM IMPLEMENTATION. THE PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 150 MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS, 4 TEACHERS, ASSOCIATED PARAPROFESSIONALS, AND THE SC

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE AREA'S STUDENTS WITH EXPERIENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES, PREPARING THEM TO BE THOUGHTFUL AND INFORMED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON BUILDING UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION FOR HOW FISH PASSAGE OBSTACLES LIMIT THE ECOSYSTEM'S FORM, FUNCTION, AND RESILIENCE. TEACHERS AND STUDENTS WILL EXPLORE DIMENSIONS SURROUNDING FISH PASSAGE AND HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, AND THEIR RESTORATION - ESPECIALLY AS THEY PERTAIN TO, BUILDING CLIMATE CHANGE RESILIENCE, POTENTIAL OUTCOMES FROM RESTORATION PROJECTS, AND HOW VALUES, CULTURE, AND TRADITION IMPACT EACH PERSON'S VIEWS SURROUNDING WATERSHED RESTORATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 150 STUDENTS FROM GRADE 5-8 FROM FIVE DOWNEAST MAINE SCHOOLS INCLUDING THE PASSAMAQUODDY TRIBE'S SIPAYIK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, CALAIS ELEMENTARY, WOODLAND ELEMENTARY, PRINCETON ELEMENTARY, AND ROSE M. GAFFNEY ELEMENTARY. THE PROJECT EXPECTS TO ENGAGE FIVE EDUCATORS, FOUR PRINCIPALS, ONE CURRICULUM COORDIN

STUDENT CLIMATE RESILIENT AMBASSADORS (SCRA) WILL USE MWEES TO EMPOWER STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES TO BE WATERSHED STEWARDS BY DESIGNING NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS TO FLOODING THAT WILL REDUCE STORM WATER RUN-OFF AND THE ASSOCIATED POLLUTANTS FROM ENTERING THE WATER SUPPLY. THEY WILL BUILD ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP THROUGH MWEES OCCURRING BOTH OUTDOORS AND IN THE CLASSROOM. MWEES WILL FOCUS ON HOW THEIR HANDS-ON EFFORTS TO MAKE HOUSTON MORE RESILIENT TO REAL AND INCREASING THREATS OF FLOODING WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO THE HEALTH OF GALVESTON BAY AND THE WATERSHED AS A WHOLE. SCRA WILL USE A MWEE APPROACH TO HELP RECONNECT URBAN NEIGHBORHOODS WITH THEIR WATERWAYS WHILE ENCOURAGING STUDENT AND COMMUNITY STEWARDSHIP. NWF WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS, BOTH IN PERSON AND VIA WEBINARS, FOCUSING ON STUDENT CENTERED LEARNING. TEACHERS WILL LEARN HOW TO USE ECO-SCHOOLS USA PROJECT-BASED LEARNING PLATFORM TO ENG

THIS PROJECT'S OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS WILL LEARN ABOUT THE CONNECTION BETWEEN THE MISSION AND ARANSAS RIVERS AND THE TEXAS GULF COAST; THE DIVERSITY, QUALITY, QUANTITY, VALUES, AND FUNCTIONS OF COASTAL NATURAL RESOURCE AREAS; HOW HUMANS IMPACT THESE AREAS; THE BENEFITS INHERENT IN PROTECTING THEM; AND ENCOURAGE ACTIONS THAT MITIGATE DAMAGE OF THE REGION'S COASTAL HABITATS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE HANDS ON, PROBLEM BASED LEARNING ACTIVITIES FOR STUDENTS AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING FOR TEACHERS AT TWO SITES WITHIN THE MISSION ARANSAS NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (MA NERR)  THE WETLANDS EDUCATION CENTER IN PORT ARANSAS, AND FENNESSEY RANCH IN REFUGIO COUNTY. OUR TARGET AUDIENCE IS 7TH GRADE MIDDLE SCHOOL TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS FROM EIGHT RURAL, UNDERSERVED SCHOOL DISTRICTS. PARTICIPATING SCHOOL DISTRICTS ARE LOCATED WITHIN THE TEXAS COASTAL ZONE BOUNDARY, SO PROJECT PARTICIPANTS WILL BE ASKED TO SUGGEST SOLUTIONS TO REAL WORLD PROBLEMS FACE

RISING SEA LEVELS AND INCREASED FREQUENCY OF TROPICAL STORMS THREATEN HUMAN INFRASTRUCTURE IN COASTAL REGIONS AND PRESENT CHALLENGES FOR MANAGEMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCES OVER A 24-MONTH PERIOD TO UP TO 20 TEACHERS AND 600 STUDENTS IN GRADES 9-11 FROM TITLE 1 SCHOOLS. STUDENTS WILL EXPLORE EXISTING LIVING SHORELINES AND BETTER UNDERSTAND AND COMMUNICATE THE BENEFITS OF LIVING SHORELINES TO PROTECT CIVIC INFRASTRUCTURE AND IMPROVE HABITAT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE. THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE THREE RECENTLY CONSTRUCTED LIVING SHORELINES WITH DIFFERENT CONFIGURATIONS TO ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 1,500 LINEAR FEET OF COAST WITHIN THE CITY OF CEDAR KEY, FLORIDA. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE NOAA B-WET PRIORITY AREA 2 "EXEMPLARY PROGRAMS THAT COMBINE TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WITH MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR THEIR STUDENTS", WITH A FOCUS ON FISHERIES. SPECIAL OBJECTIVES ARE: A) IMPROVE STUDENTS' UN

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT TWO, YEAR-LONG, INTERDISCIPLINARY, SINGLE-USE PLASTIC-THEMED MWEES THAT FOSTER TAMPA BAY STEWARDSHIP AMONG 2ND AND 3RD GRADERS. STUDENTS WILL BECOME FAMILIAR WITH THE LOCAL WATERSHED AND THE FISHERIES WHICH DEPEND ON IT; MAKE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN EVERYDAY ACTIVITIES AND HEALTH OF THE WATERSHED; INCREASE AWARENESS OF HARMFUL EFFECTS OF SINGLE-USE PLASTICS, INCLUDING THE RISKS TO WATERSHEDS; EXPLORE ALTERNATIVES TO SINGLE-USE PLASTICS AND ULTIMATELY REDUCE THEIR USE; RECOGNIZE INDIVIDUAL ACTIONS MAKE A DIFFERENCE; AND INCREASE STUDENT SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP FOR THE ENVIRONMENT THROUGH WATERSHED PROTECTION. WE AIM TO CREATE A COMMUNITY OF YOUNG ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS WHO ARE ACUTELY AWARE OF THEIR PLASTIC CONSUMPTION AND THEIR ROLE IN PREVENTING MARINE DEBRIS WITHIN THE WATERSHED. THE MWEES ARE DESIGNED FOR SUSTAINED EXPOSURE. BOTH STUDENTS AND TEACHERS WILL REVISIT PLASTIC POLLUTION AND THE LINK TO WATERSHED HEALTH ACROSS DISCIPLINES AND TH

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE PROVIDE TEACHERS WITH INTERACTIVE AND ENGAGING LESSON PLANS TO USE WITH STUDENTS TO BOTH INCREASE CONTENT KNOWLEDGE AND TO FACILITATE STEWARDSHIP IN THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITY; INCREASE TEACHER CONFIDENCE IN TEACHING POLLUTION CONTENT TO STUDENTS USING MWEES; AND ENGAGE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN LOCAL RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGH THE USE OF A HANDS-ON ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECT IN TAMPA BAY. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE OBJECTIVES, A TEACHER WORKSHOP ON MICROPLASTICS POLLUTION WILL BE HOSTED AT THE FLORIDA AQUARIUM, FOLLOWED BY THE FIELD COLLECTION OF OYSTERS FROM MULTIPLE SITES IN TAMPA BAY, AND PROCESSING OF OYSTERS BY THE INVERTEBRATE LABORATORY AT USFSP. TEACHERS AND STUDENTS WILL DO A VISUAL ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE LEVELS OF MICROPLASTICS POLLUTION IN THE SAMPLES, FOLLOWED BY A HANDS-ON OYSTER RESTORATION PROJECT LED BY TAMPA BAY WATCH.

SOLUTION TO POLLUTION IS A SYSTEMIC MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT WITH A PRIMARY FOCUS ON THE DEVELOPING DISTRICT-WIDE CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT THE MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEE) FRAMEWORK. THE SOLUTION TO POLLUTION PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS THE DISCIPLINES OF OCEANOGRAPHY, AQUATIC SCIENCES, CONSERVATION BIOLOGY, ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AND ECOLOGY IN 6-12TH GRADES OF FLOUR BLUFF INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT (FBISD). SOLUTION TO POLLUTION WILL ALSO ADVANCE PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED BY THE GULF OF MEXICO ALLIANCE INCLUDING 1) MARINE DEBRIS WITH A GOAL TO "ASSESS, PREVENT, REMOVE, AND ELIMINATE MARINE DEBRIS AND LITTER IN THE GULF OF MEXICO AND ITS WATERSHEDS TO ENHANCE WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, HABITATS, WATER RESOURCES, HUMANS, AND THE GULF ECONOMY" AND 2) EDUCATION AND ENGAGEMENT WITH A GOAL TO "ENHANCE COLLABORATION AND STEWARDSHIP IN THE GULF OF MEXICO AND ITS WATERSHED THROUGH EDUCATION AND ENGAGEMENT FOCUSED ON ALLIA

SEACAMP IS A NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION THAT PROVIDES MARINE SCIENCE EDUCATION TO STUDENTS FROM GRADES 4 AND UP. SEACAMP IS LOCATED AT THE SOUTH END OF BIG PINE KEY, AND DUE TO OUR UNIQUE LOCATION AND SERVICES WE BELIEVE THAT WE CAN PROVIDE A VALUABLE EXPERIENCE FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN ABOUT THE ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE OF WATERSHEDS FROM THE BOTTOM UP. SEA CAMP PROPOSES TO PROVIDE A PROGRAM TO OVER 300 5TH GRADERS FROM HENDRY COUNTY, FL THAT TEACHES STUDENTS HOW HUMAN ACTION IMPACTS THE ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC FACTORS OF WATERSHEDS THROUGH AN INDEX OF BIOTIC INTEGRITY (IBI) PROJECT THAT IS MODIFIED FOR 5TH GRADE SCIENCE STANDARDS. HENDRY COUNTY ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS ARE ALL TITLE 1 SCHOOLS, MEANING THAT AT LEAST 40% OF EACH SCHOOL'S STUDENT POPULATION COMES FROM LOW INCOME FAMILIES. SEACAMP IS REACHING OUT TO THESE SCHOOLS TO HAVE STUDENTS EXPERIENCE A PROGRAM FOR THREE DAYS AND TWO NIGHTS THAT WILL IMMERSE THEM IN SOME OF THE MOST DIVERSE HABITATS IN THE WORLD. OVER THE COURSE OF THE 12-MONTH PROJECT

MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY'S GULF COAST COMMUNITY DESIGN STUDIO (GCCDS), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MOSS POINT SCHOOL DISTRICT AND PASCAGOULA RIVER AUDUBON CENTER PROPOSES IMPLEMENTING A TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM AND STUDENT MWEE'S WORKING WITH THE MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOLS IN THE MOSS POINT SCHOOL DISTRICT. APPROXIMATELY 7 TEACHERS AND THE DISTRICT'S SCIENCE INSTRUCTIONAL COACH (ADMINISTRATION) WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM DURING THE 2023-2024 ACADEMIC YEAR AND APPROXIMATELY 175 STUDENTS (8TH GRADERS AND THE FOUNDATIONS TO BIOLOGY 9TH GRADE CLASSES) WILL PARTICIPATE IN MWEE'S DURING THE 2024-2025 ACADEMIC YEAR. IN ADDITION, APPROXIMATELY 30 YOUTH WILL PARTICIPATE IN TWO PILOT EXTRACURRICULAR PROGRAMS WITH THE PASCAGOULA RIVER AUDUBON CENTER WITH A MODIFIED CURRICULUM GEARED TOWARD SUMMER AND OUT-OF-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. THE GEOGRAPHICAL BASIS FOR THE PROGRAMMING WILL BE THE RHODES BAYOU WATERSHED. RHODES BAYOU IS A LARGE URBAN TIDAL STREAM LOCATED IN

THE COOPERATIVE PROGRAM FOR EARTH SYSTEM EDUCATION (CPESE) FROM THE AMERICAN METEOROLOGICAL SOCIETY (AMS) AND NOAA SHARES KNOWLEDGE AND INFORMATION ABOUT WEATHER AND CLIMATE, OCEAN, AND COASTS WITH IN-SERVICE AND PRE-SERVICE TEACHERS, K-12 AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. CPESE SUPPORTS THE 2021-2040 NOAA EDUCATION STRATEGIC PLAN GOALS OF SCIENCE-INFORMED SOCIETY; READY, RESPONSIVE, AND RESILIENT; AND FUTURE WORKFORCE. THROUGH THIS AWARD CPESE WILL PROVIDE: (1) PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (PD) AT A NATIONAL SCALE FOR K-12 EDUCATORS; (2) FELLOWSHIPS FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS IN ATMOSPHERIC, OCEANIC, AND HYDROLOGIC SCIENCES; AND (3) A PLANNING YEAR FOR REIMAGINING THE AMS MODEL AND METHODS OF TEACHER PD COURSE DELIVERY, WORKING WITH INSTRUCTIONAL DESIGNERS AND DIVERSITY, EQUITY AND INCLUSION CONSULTANTS WITH GOALS THAT  INCLUDE REACHING MORE UNDERSERVED TEACHERS/SCHOOLS AND REACHING CLIMATE-VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF CPESE ARE TO: (1) CREATE A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE COMPRISED OF A DIVE

BROCKTON, MASSACHUSETTS IS A FANTASTICALLY DIVERSE BUT IMPOVERISHED CITY AND DESIGNATED ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITY WITH A RICH HISTORY. IT IS HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO FLOODING, POLLUTION, AND WATER SUPPLY DISRUPTIONS RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AND ITS SCHOOL SYSTEM FACES SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGES. IT HAS BEEN HARD-HIT BY COVID-19. BROCKTON IS ALSO A CITY WITH A LONG HISTORY OF RESILIENCE IN THE FACE OF ECONOMIC CHALLENGES AND A THIRST FOR EMPOWERMENT AND OPPORTUNITY. THIS PROJECT WILL  BOOST CLIMATE RESILIENCE IN BROCKTON BY PARTNERING WITH SCHOOLS TO (1) SUSTAINABLY BOOST SCHOOL CAPACITY TO DEVELOP ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND RESILIENCE IN STUDENTS BY COLLABORATING TO DESIGN AND BUILD OUTDOOR LEARNING SPACES ON SCHOOL GROUNDS, AND TO PROVIDE TEACHERS WITH CURRICULAR TOOLS AND TRAINING FOR USE, (2) EMPOWER ELEMENTARY STUDENTS AND TEACHERS AS ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS THROUGH OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, ENGAGING IN STEWARDSHIP ACTION TO BUILD GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT

MINNESOTA AND WISCONSIN COMMUNITIES ARE FACING MULTIPLE CLIMATE-RELATED HAZARDS INCLUDING WILDFIRES, DROUGHT, POLLUTION, SEVERE STORMS AND FLOODING, HEALTH EMERGENCIES, AND HABITAT AND SPECIES LOSS. TO BUILD A STRONG YOUTH COMPONENT TO STATE CLIMATE RESILIENCY EFFORTS, TWIN CITIES PUBLIC BROADCASTING STATION (PBS), THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-SUPERIOR, UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA'S HENNEPIN COUNTY 4-H PROGRAM, NATIVE SUN'S YOUTH PROGRAM IN THE RED LAKE NATION, AND THE UNIVERSITY CORPORATION FOR ATMOSPHERIC RESEARCH WILL SUPPORT PLACE-BASED LEARNING ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY WITH MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH USING NOAA ASSETS AND ELEVATE THEIR VOICES THROUGH A NEW PUBLIC MEDIA PODCAST SERIES FOR YOUTH. AT THE ANNUAL YOUTH CLIMATE JUSTICE SUMMIT IN ST. PAUL, MINNESOTA AND AT SUPERIOR DAYS IN MADISON, WISCONSIN STUDENTS WILL SHARE THEIR SOLUTIONS WITH LEGISLATORS. MULTIPLE PUBLIC MEDIA PLATFORMS WILL CARRY PODCASTS INCLUDING MINNESOTA PUBLIC RADIO'S AMERICAN PUBLIC MEDIA AND

THROUGH THE "CLIMATE RESILIENT FLINT: BUILDING COMMUNITY-DRIVEN CLIMATE RESILIENCE THROUGH HYPERLOCAL SCIENCE-TO-CIVICS LEARNING IN FLINT, MI,"  PROJECT KETTERING UNIVERSITY PARTNERS WITH DEDICATED COMMUNITY-BASED NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS,  CITY OFFICIALS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS FROM UNDER-RESOURCED NEIGHBORHOODS TO PLAY AN INTEGRAL ROLE IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING A CLIMATE RESILIENCE INITIATIVE FOR FLINT, MICHIGAN. THROUGH DELIBERATIVE COMMUNITY FORUMS, NEIGHBORHOOD PROJECTS, AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE EDUCATION AND TRAINING, THE THREE-YEAR PROJECT WILL FOSTER PARTICIPANTS' AWARENESS OF EXTREME HEAT AND PRECIPITATION EVENTS PROJECTED FOR THE FUTURE AND GUIDE THEIR DEVELOPMENT OF CLIMATE RESILIENT STRATEGIES TO IMPLEMENT AT THE NEIGHBORHOOD SCALE. PROJECT COMPONENTS WILL BE SPEARHEADED BY COMMUNITY VISION AND NEED, ALIGNED WITH THE CITY'S MASTER PLAN, AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE CITY'S BUDDING ENVIRONMENTAL AND SUSTAINABILITY PLAN. CLIMATE RESILIENT FLINT IS INTENDED T

COASTAL FAITH COMMUNITIES CAN BE KEY ASSETS TO BUILDING RESILIENCE IN THEIR COMMUNITIES, BUT DO NOT HAVE THE RESOURCES OR INVESTMENT FROM RESILIENCE AGENCIES TO BUILD THE NECESSARY ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE NETWORKS OF FAITH COMMUNITIES THAT ARE EDUCATED ON THE REALITIES OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND ABLE TO SERVE AS HUBS OF SOCIAL AND PHYSICAL RESILIENCE FOR THEIR COMMUNITIES  HELPING THEM BETTER WEATHER THE PHYSICAL, SOCIAL, AND SPIRITUAL STORMS OF THE CLIMATE CRISIS. THIS PROJECT WILL (1) ENGAGE FAITH COMMUNITIES IN SOCIAL LEARNING ON THE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THEIR EXPERIENCE OF EXTREME WEATHER AND THE SCIENCE OF CLIMATE CHANGE, (2) FACILITATE A SERIES OF WORKSHOPS IN WHICH FAITH COMMUNITIES ENGAGE WITH LOCAL SCIENTISTS, PLANNERS, AND DECISION-MAKERS AROUND CLIMATE RESILIENCE TO EXTREME WEATHER AND CLIMATE CHANGE, AND (3) GUIDE CONGREGATIONS THROUGH A RESILIENCE IMPLEMENTATION AND EDUCATIONAL PROJECT. THE PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IN RU

WASHINGTON DCS WARD 7 IS HOME TO NOT ONLY THE MAJORITY OF SINGLE-FAMILY HOMES IN WASHINGTON, DCS 100-YEAR FLOODPLAIN, BUT ALSO A PREDOMINANTLY BLACK POPULATION THAT FACES INCREASED CLIMATE VULNERABILITY DUE TO SOCIO-ECONOMIC STRESSORS AND LEGACIES OF SYSTEMIC RACISM. THE FH FAUNTEROY COMMUNITY ENRICHMENT CENTER WILL LEAD INTERGENERATIONAL EFFORTS TO BUILD CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND ADDRESS COMPLEX ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS WITH WARD 7 RESIDENTS THROUGH A MODEL BUILT ON SELF-DETERMINATION AND COLLABORATION WITH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTNERS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMMING, ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, AND DEVELOPING COMMUNITY-DRIVEN DECISION-MAKING PROCESSES AND STRUCTURES. THE PROJECT IS SUPPORTED BY NOAA OFFICES AND LEVERAGES NOAA ASSETS TO INTEGRATE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION, CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE, AND DIVERSE COMMUNITY VALUES INTO RESILIENCE HUB PROGRAMMING AND PARTNERSHIPS. THESE EFFORTS WILL INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESILIENCE HUBS IN WARD 7 AND THROUGHOUT DC TO HELP VU

WE STAY/NOS QUEDAMOS, INC. IS A LEADER IN COMMUNITY-DRIVEN SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT FOR MELROSE RESIDENTS IN THE SOUTH BRONX (NY), WITH A 30-YEAR HISTORY OF ORGANIZING AND SUPPORTING  THE PRESERVATION OF OPEN SPACE, ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH, AND SOCIAL JUSTICE. THIS  PROJECT WILL UPLIFT THE ENERGY AND WISDOM OF LOCAL YOUTH LEADERS AND ORGANIZERS TO EDUCATE AND ENGAGE THEIR PEERS, FAMILY MEMBERS, AND NEIGHBORS AROUND CLIMATE IMPACTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE, TO PREPARE FOR THE EFFECTIVE ACTIVATION OF THREE CLIMATE RESILIENCY HUBS CURRENTLY IN DEVELOPMENT. AN ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY TEAM WILL CONDUCT DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS; LEAD WORKSHOPS, TRAININGS, AND COMMUNITY EVENTS; AND HOLD A SYMPOSIUM WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS, CITY AND STATE AGENCIES, AND ELECTED OFFICIALS TO LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR RESILIENCE PLANNING AND POLICY AWARENESS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE MELROSE COMMUNITY WILL OBTAIN THE DATA, KNOWLEDGE, TALKING POINTS, AND THE PEOPLE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED TO INCREASE MELROSES CLIMATE

SOLAR ONE AND NEWARK OFFICE OF SUSTAINABILITY ARE PROPOSING THE NEWARK RESILIENT SOLAR INITIATIVE TO SUPPORT YOUTH IN BUILDING THE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY, CAREER READINESS, AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS NEEDED TO BE CHANGE AGENTS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. YOUTH PARTICIPANTS WILL ACHIEVE THIS THROUGH EDUCATION AND WORK BASED LEARNING THAT CULMINATE IN THE INSTALLATION OF RESILIENT SOLAR SYSTEMS, PLACED STRATEGICALLY IN NEWARK'S MOST VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES, A PROCESS GUIDED BY COMMUNITY MEMBERS, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONAL PARTNERS AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE LEADERS. THESE SYSTEMS WILL BUILD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE HAZARDS BY ENABLING NEWARKERS TO ACCESS ELECTRICITY DURING A POWER OUTAGE. THEY ARE ALSO A CATALYST FOR COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT EVENTS THAT USE NOAA ASSETS TO BUILD COLLECTIVE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY, EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS, AND SOCIAL COHESION IN ALIGNMENT WITH LOCAL RESILIENCE GOALS. THE RESILIENT SOLAR INITIATIVE SUPPORTS A COORDINATOR POSITION WITHIN THE OFFICE OF SUSTAINABILITY

COMMUNITIES IN COLORADO ARE INCREASINGLY EXPERIENCING MAJOR DISRUPTIONS FROM ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS AND VULNERABLE COMMUNITY MEMBERS ARE OFTEN DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY THESE HAZARDS. COLORADO TEACHERS NEED RESOURCES TO TEACH COMMUNITY RESILIENCE. THE NOAA COOPERATIVE INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH IN ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES WILL BUILD ON A SUCCESSFUL YOUTH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROJECT THAT INSPIRES AND EMPOWERS RURAL COLORADO MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS TO ACT AS THE CHANGE AGENTS TO BUILD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE AGAINST NATURAL HAZARDS (PRIOR NOAA AWARD NA18SEC0080007). TWO IMPLEMENTATION TIERS WILL  SUPPLY THESE RESOURCES. TIER 1 WILL CONTINUE TO ENGAGE TEACHERS AND STUDENTS FROM RURAL COLORADO COMMUNITIES IN SCENARIO-BASED ROLE-PLAY, COMMUNITY PREPAREDNESS, AND FUNDED RESILIENCE ACTION PROJECTS. TIER 2 WILL BUILD ON AND EXPAND THE INNOVATIVE HEART FORCE ENGAGEMENT MODEL BY FOCUSING ON VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES AND ENGAGING EXPERIENCED HEART FORCE TEACHERS IN DEVELOP

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSED GRANT PROJECT IS TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE AMONG A SOCIALLY VULNERABLE AND MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATION IN ROANOKE, VIRGINIA AND MORE BROADLY THROUGHOUT SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA. THIS INITIATIVE WILL EDUCATE AND ENGAGE HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, STUDENTS/EDUCATORS, URBAN PLANNERS,  AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS IN BUILDING CLIMATE RESILIENCY FOR THE REGION. BUILDING OFF A RECENT NOAA-FUNDED STUDY WHICH LOOKED AT THE IMPACTS OF HEAT ON THE URBAN POPULATION IN ROANOKE, THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS INITIATIVE IS TO PILOT A REPRODUCIBLE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY CAMPAIGN THAT COMBINES APPROACHES TO HEAT MANAGEMENT AND HEAT MITIGATIONS STRATEGIES, LED BY A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN PUBLIC HEALTH AND MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS, URBAN PLANNING EXPERTS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INTRA- AND INTER-GROUP LEARNING AND ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH AND ADULT RESIDENTS, HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS, AND CITY OFFICIALS IN ROANOKE.

FUNDS ARE REQUESTED TO SUPPORT THE 7TH YOUNG COASTAL SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS CONFERENCE - AMERICAS (YCSECA). THIS CONFERENCE BRINGS TOGETHER GRADUATE STUDENTS, POST DOCS, AND YOUNG PROFESSIONALS TO SHARE THEIR RESEARCH IN A NON-INTIMIDATING ENVIRONMENT ENABLING NETWORK BUILDING. THE CONFERENCE WILL BE HELD IN MYRTLE BEACH, SC FOLLOWING ALL LOCAL COVID SAFETY PROTOCOLS. THERE ARE OVER 90 PARTICIPANTS REGISTERED TO PRESENT. SUPPORT FROM INDUSTRY, ACADEMIA AND GOVERNMENT ENABLES US TO KEEP THE REGISTRATION COST LOW ENABLING PARTICIPATION FOR STUDENTS FROM A WIDE RANGE OF INSTITUTIONS. THE REQUESTED FUNDS MEET SEVERAL NOAA PROGRAM PRIORITIES INCLUDING CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION AND WEATHER-READY NATION. THE YCSECA PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR YOUNG RESEARCHERS THAT ARE, AND WILL BECOME THE FUTURE WORKFORCE, TO DISCUSS AND ADDRESS SCIENCE TOPICS RELATED TO THESE PRIORITIES.

THE MARINE BOARD OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES, ENGINEERING AND MEDICINE IS A RECOGNIZED SOURCE OF EXPERTISE ON MARINE TRANSPORTATION, MARINE TECHNOLOGY, AND OFFSHORE DEVELOPMENT.  THE MARINE BOARD IDENTIFIES RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT NEEDS AND PROVIDES A FORUM FOR INFORMATION EXCHANGE CONCERNING THESE AREAS AROUND MARINE TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS AND OFFSHORE INDUSTRIES.  THE MARIN EBOARD WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE OF AN INDEPENDENT BOARD, MAINTAIN ONGOING REVIEW OF ACTIVITIES TRACKING PROGRESS AND IDENTIFYING NEW INITIATIVES, MAINTAIN REFERENCE MATERIAL, SERVE AS A SOURCE OF INFORMATION, CONDUCT INVESTIGATIONS AND DEVELOP PROBLEM STATEMENTS FOR NEW PROJECTS.

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROMOTE INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC COLLABORATION IN MARINE ECOSYSTEM RESEARCH. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PICES, AN INTERGOVERNMENTAL SCIENTIFIC ORGANIZATION, WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1992 TO PROMOTE AND COORDINATE MARINE RESEARCH IN THE NORTHERN NORTH PACIFIC AND ADJACENT SEAS.  FUNDING WILL SUPPORT AN INTERN PROGRAM AS WELL AS THREE PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS. THE INTERN PROGRAM WILL HELP YOUNG PROFESSIONALS TO DEVELOP THE SKILLS NEEDED TO OPERATE IN A CROSS NATIONAL ENVIRONMENT AS WELL AS ENGAGE WITH THE GLOBAL SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY.  THE THREE SUPPORTED SYMPOSIA WILL EACH ENHANCE INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC COLLABORATION AND WILL LIKELY RESULT IN A COLLECTION OF RELEVANT, PEER-REVIEWED PAPERS THAT WILL SERVE AS RESOURCES TO IMPROVE PUBLIC DISCOURSE ABOUT ECOSYSTEM AND RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP EXPECTED OUTCOMES:  YOUNG SCIENTISTS IN THE MARINE RESEARCH FIELD WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE AT THE INTERNATIONAL LEVEL IN INCREASING COLLABORATION AND UNDERSTANDING WITH LARG

THE GOAL OF THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE, EXPAND, AND SUSTAIN THE ABILITY OF EDUCATORS IN ALABAMA AND OTHER GULF OF MEXICO STATES TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) FOCUSED ON UNDERSTANDING, DETECTING, AND MITIGATING PATHOGEN POLLUTION IN LOCAL WATERS. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, THE PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF THE NOAA B-WET FUNDED ALABAMA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SYSTEM, 4-H AL WATER WATCH PROJECT, EXPLORING AND MITIGATING PATHOGEN POLLUTION IN OUR WATERS, TO IMPLEMENT FOUR MAJOR OBJECTIVES. 1) MAKE IMPROVEMENTS TO THE EXPLORING PATHOGEN POLLUTION IN OUR WATERS CURRICULUM AND PROJECT BASED ON FEEDBACK THAT WILL BE GATHERED FROM APPROXIMATELY 10 COASTAL EDUCATORS WHO WERE TRAINED DURING THE PILOT PHASE OF THE PROJECT, HAVE ENGAGED THEIR STUDENTS IN MWEES GUIDED BY THE PROJECT CURRICULUM, AND WHO INTEND TO CONTINUE THEIR PARTICIPATION WITH THE PROJECT. 2) CONDUCT PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAININGS (ONE PER PROJECT YEAR) TO TRAIN A TOTAL O

THE "ISLAND STYLE - SYSTEMIC TRAINING FOR YOUTH LEADERSHIP IN THE ENVIRONMENT" WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT SYSTEMIC MWEE'S AT THE GALVESTON INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT (GISD) FOR ALL SIXTH-GRADE STUDENTS (450 STUDENTS) ON THE AUSTIN CAMPUS AND DELIVER A 40-HOUR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO 23+ SIXTH-GRADE TEACHERS. THE PROJECT WILL UTILIZE PARTNERS FROM NOAA, GISD STAFF, AREA NON-PROFITS, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF HOUSTON TO DEVELOP, DESIGN, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE THE PROGRAM. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE TWENTY IN-CLASS AND FIELD-BASED LESSONS THAT WILL RESULT IN AN ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION PROJECT AND PRESENTATION OF RESULTS AT A SCHOOL CONFERENCE, BASED AROUND THE DRIVING QUESTION OF HOW THE GULF OF MEXICO, GALVESTON BAY, AND GALVESTON ISLAND ADD VALUE TO THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR PEOPLE AND IF THIS VALUE CAN BE CHANGED. DELIVERY METHODS WILL INCLUDE MEETINGS TO DESIGN, AUTHOR, IMPLEMENT, DELIVER, AND EVALUATE THE MODEL; SUMMER TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND COMPANION SUPPOR

HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN SANTA ROSA AND ESCAMBIA COUNTIES (FLORIDA) WILL PARTICIPATE IN MWEES THAT INVESTIGATE RESTORATION AND RESILIENCE THROUGH THE LENS OF PENSACOLA BAY SYSTEM (PBS) OYSTERS. STUDENTS WILL EXPLORE CLIMATE CHANGE, RESILIENCE, AND RESTORATION THROUGH INQUIRY BASED FIELD TRIPS AND ANALYSIS OF LOCAL DATA SETS, CASE STUDIES, AND HISTORICAL RECORDS. TEACHERS WILL BE EQUIPPED TO GUIDE THESE MWEES THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN A WEEK-LONG SUMMER WORKSHOP THAT COVERS THE MWEE FRAMEWORK; OYSTER SPAT FIELD MONITORING PROTOCOLS AND ANALYSIS; OYSTER HATCHERY, FARM, AND RESTORATION FIELD TRIPS; GUEST PRESENTATIONS; AND EXAMINATION OF LOCALLY RELEVANT DATA SETS AND MODELS. AT THE END OF THEIR INQUIRY-BASED EXPLORATIONS, STUDENTS WILL PRESENT THEIR RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LOCATIONS TO DEPLOY STUDENT-BUILT OYSTER GARDENING CAGES. DELIVERY METHODS: 1. WEEK-LONG SUMMER TEACHER WORKSHOP (GUEST SPEAKERS, HATCHERY AND OYSTER FARM TOURS, RESTORATION SITE TOURS, FIELD SPAT MONITORING); 2

FLOW WILL FACILITATE SYSTEMIC MWEE IMPLEMENTATION FOR THE ENTIRE 8TH GRADE IN THESE MARGINALIZED RURAL COMMUNITIES IN ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST PARISH. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN WATERSHED LITERACY FOR ALL 8TH GRADE SCIENCE TEACHERS FOLLOWED BY ONGOING SUPPORT AND MENTORING. IT WILL DEVELOP, TEST, AND IMPLEMENT AN INCLUSIVE AND LOCALLY-FOCUSED MWEE WATERSHED CURRICULUM IN COLLABORATION WITH THESE SCIENCE TEACHERS AND WILL REACH BEYOND SCIENCE CLASSES TO INCLUDE COLLABORATION WITH MATH, SOCIAL STUDIES, AND ART CURRICULUM SPECIALISTS. THIS PROJECT WILL TRAIN AND ENABLE TEACHERS, UNDER PC GUIDANCE, TO CREATE STEM KITS. THESE KITS ARE A FEATURE OF PC'S FLOW: ST. BERNARD PARISH (A CURRENT NOAA BWET PROJECT). THE KITS PROVIDE HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE TO STUDENTS IN INQUIRY-DRIVEN INVESTIGATIONS ON A VARIETY OF TOPICS RANGING FROM WATER QUALITY TESTING, TO MARINE DEBRIS AND MICROPLASTICS, TO CLIMATE EDUCATION AND OTHER COASTAL TOPICS SUCH AS THE EFFECTS OF COAS

THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE K-12 CLIMATE LITERACY EDUCATION AND USE OF MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES (MWEES) ACROSS FLORIDA BY LEVERAGING CAPACITY BUILDING THROUGH A BOTTOM-UP MODEL WITH AN AUDIENCE OF COLLABORATORS FROM K-12 SCHOOLS, STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCIES, NONPROFITS FOR EDUCATION & CONSERVATION, AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT ACTORS.  LED BY THE CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENT & SOCIETY AT FLORIDA GULF COAST UNIVERSITY, A LARGE STATE UNIVERSITY WITH A STRATEGIC FOCUS ON CLIMATE CHANGE RESEARCH & EDUCATION, AND THE LEAGUE OF ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATORS IN FLORIDA (LEEF), THE STATEWIDE CHAPTER OF THE NORTH AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION (NAAEE), PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: (1) DEVELOP A STATEWIDE ADVISORY GROUP WITH STAKEHOLDERS DRAWN FROM K-12 EDUCATION, STATE AGENCIES FOR ENVIRONMENT; NONPROFITS IN CONSERVATION & EDUCATION; EQUITY-DRIVEN ORGANIZATIONS LIKE NAACP; AND INDUSTRY AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT; (2) LEVERAGE CAPACITY OF THE ADVISORY GROUP

THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (LDOE) (2020) REPORTED THAT 4.19% OF STUDENTS (OR AROUND 28,915) WERE LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY. AS LOUISIANA HAS IMPLEMENTED EDUCATION CHANGES THAT IMPROVE INSTRUCTION AND STUDENT PERFORMANCE, THE ACHIEVEMENT GAP FOR ELS REMAINS STAGNANT. LOUISIANA TEACHERS RECEIVE VERY LITTLE INSTRUCTION IN SCIENCE AND SOCIAL STUDIES, LET ALONE WITH ESL COURSES. THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO CREATE AUTHENTIC SCIENCE AND LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR THE FORMAL EDUCATION OF TEACHERS IN COASTAL LOUISIANA. TEACHERS WILL BE PROVIDED EXPERIENCES, RESOURCES, AND METHODS ON HOW TO TEACH EL STUDENTS. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE TEACHER KNOWLEDGE OF ESL TEACHING TECHNIQUES, IMPROVE ELL KNOWLEDGE OF SCIENTIFIC VOCABULARY, AND PROVIDE RELEVANT, HANDS-ON LEARNING. TEACHERS WILL EXAMINE HOW CULTURAL DIFFERENCES CAN IMPACT A STUDENT'S EDUCATION AND HOW TO MEET THESE NEEDS. TEACHERS WILL ALSO HAVE AN OPPORTUNITY TO ENHANCE THEIR SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE BY EXAMINING THE PONTCHARTRAIN BASIN (PB)

THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN MARITIME MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP ON-THE-WATER LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR K-12 STUDENTS AND TEACHERS AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS THAT WILL BUILD STEWARDSHIP BEHAVIORS THROUGH MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATION EXPERIENCES (MWEES). "LEARNING FROM THE LAKE" WILL BUILD UPON WHAT HAS WORKED WELL FROM 20 YEARS OF ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, LEARN FROM THE IMPACTS OF COVID-19, AND CREATE A SUSTAINABLE FUTURE FOR WATERSHED EDUCATION IN VERMONT'S LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN.   THIS NEW ENGLAND BAY WATERSHED EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROJECT FOCUSES ON "CAPACITY BUILDING FOR SUSTAINABILITY" WITH THREE COMPONENTS:  1. ON-THE-WATER PROGRAMS: FREE MWEES FOR STUDENTS AT THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN MARITIME MUSEUM AND NEARBY FIELD SITES WITH NEW PRE-AND POST-VISIT CLASSROOM DIGITAL LEARNING MODULES.  2. SUMMER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT: FREE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS MODELING MWEE ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS AND SUPPORTING PRACTICES.  3. YEAR-ROUND COMMUNIT

"RIVERS TO SEA", IS FOR STUDENTS FROM LOW-INCOME, UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS IN MASSACHUSETTS.  ITS PURPOSE IS TO EMPOWER THEM TO RESOLVE ISSUES THAT AFFECT THEIR LOCAL WATERSHED, TO ENSURE THE WATERSHED REMAINS HEALTHY FOR THE HUMAN AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES THAT LIVE THERE, AND TO BUILD THE FOUNDATION OF A MORE ENVIRONMENTALLY LITERATE CITIZENRY IN NEW ENGLAND. IT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WITH SEVEN TITLE 1 PUBLIC SCHOOL PARTNERS IN NORTHEASTERN, SOUTHEASTERN, AND WESTERN MASSACHUSETTS. A TOTAL OF 1,410 4TH- AND 5TH-GRADE STUDENTS WILL EACH RECEIVE 16 CONTACT HOURS OF PROGRAMMING (22,560 STUDENT CONTACT HOURS), AND APPROXIMATELY 40% OF THAT CONTACT TIME WILL BE OUTDOORS.   OBJECTIVES AND OUTCOMES FOR THE 3-YEAR PROJECT INCLUDE:  (1) DEVELOPMENT OF A 4-MODULE RIVERS TO SEA CURRICULUM FOCUSED ON SOLVING PROBLEMS IN THE LOCAL WATERSHEDS.  (2) ENGAGING STUDENTS WITH STEWARDSHIP ACTION LEARNING EXPERIENCES.  (3) PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING (40 CONTACT HOURS/EDUCATOR) F

THE NATIONAL NETWORK FOR OCEAN AND CLIMATE CHANGE INTERPRETATION IS WORKING WITH THE MARINE MAMMAL CENTER, KNOLOGY, AND THE FRAMEWORKS INSTITUTE TO BUILD NATIONAL CAPACITY FOR EVIDENCE-BASED CLIMATE COMMUNICATION THROUGH INNOVATIVE TRAINING PROGRAMS AND A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE THAT ENGAGES EDUCATORS, SCIENTISTS, COMMUNITY ACTIVISTS, AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. NEARLY TWO-THIRDS OF AMERICANS TALK ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE ONLY OCCASIONALLY OR NOT AT ALL, RESULTING IN A LACK OF ACTION TO ADDRESS ONE OF THE MOST CRITICAL ISSUES OF OUR TIME. THE NATIONAL NETWORK FOR OCEAN AND CLIMATE CHANGE INTERPRETATION HAS WORKED FOR MORE THAN A DECADE TO ADVANCE THE SCIENCE AND PRACTICE OF EFFECTIVE PUBLIC COMMUNICATION AROUND CLIMATE CHANGE BY DEVELOPING, EVALUATING AND DEPLOYING COMMUNICATIONS TOOLS THAT EMPLOY BOTH CUTTING-EDGE CLIMATE SCIENCE AND COMMUNICATION RESEARCH TO INCREASE BOTH KNOWLEDGE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND A WILLINGNESS TO ENGAGE IN CLIMATE ACTION. THE NETWORK'S COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE OFFERS RES
SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA COLLABORATIVE FOR RESILIENCE THROUGH EDUCATION AND DECISION-MAKING (SACRED)

"RESILIENCEMT: MONTANA RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITY CLIMATE RESILIENCE EXHIBIT AND FORUMS" EDUCATION AND ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WILL ENHANCE THE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY OF OVER 2,000 MONTANANS, INCLUDING YOUTH AND ADULTS, AND SUPPORT COMMUNITY CLIMATE RESILIENCE PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, AND CAPACITY BUILDING. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR ADAPTIVE CAPACITY RELATED TO (1) WILDFIRES AND ASSOCIATED IMPACTS ON HUMAN HEALTH, STATE AND LOCAL BUDGETS, AND MONTANA'S TOURISM AND RECREATION ECONOMIES; (2) DROUGHT AND IMPACTS ON CROPS, AGRICULTURAL ECONOMIES, WILDLIFE AND GAME SPECIES, AND CULTURALLY-SIGNIFICANT PLANTS; AND (3) FLOODING DUE TO EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS AND CHANGES IN AMOUNT AND TIMING OF SPRING SNOWMELT AND ASSOCIATED IMPACTS ON WATER SUPPLIES, RECREATION, AND FISHING. IMPACTS ASSOCIATED WITH OUR CHANGING CLIMATE ARE ALREADY OCCURRING, AND RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE AND LESS PREPARED THAN LARGER COMMUNITIES.   PROJECT OBJECTIVES I

THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO EXPLORE MODEL ENGINES AND DEVELOP 3D CAPABILITIES (I.E., STRATIFICATION) IN ORDER TO PROVIDE AN INFRASTRUCTURE THAT CAN SUPPORT COASTAL AND OCEAN MODELS THAT EXTEND FROM THE OCEAN BASIN (DEEP OCEAN WATERS) THROUGH THE COASTAL ZONE AND UP TO LAND WATERSHED NETWORK (RIVERINE), AND ALSO FOR THE GREAT LAKES. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE DEVELOPING "BASIN-TO-CREEK" CAPABILITY, EVALUATING WATER QUALITY THROUGH A FLEXIBLE PROCESS COUPLING APPROACH, UNDERSTANDING THE POTENTIAL REQUIREMENT FOR TRANSITIONING SUCH AN EFFORT TO AN OPERATION SERVICE, AND EVALUATING THE PERFORMANCE OF THE MODEL OVER TIME AND SPATIAL RESOLUTION. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE A DETAILED INVESTIGATION FOR AN ESTUARINE SYSTEM (E.G. CHESAPEAKE BAY) FOR CREATING A LONG-TERM HINDCAST, FILLING IN THE GAP OF MISSING COMPOUND FLOODING ZONES IN THE UP-RIVER AND WATERSHED AREAS, AND DEVELOPING A NOVEL COMPOUND FLOODING MODEL FOR LAKE SUPERIOR.

THIS PROJECT REQUEST IS IN RESPONSE TO THE NOAA BAA TO ENCOURAGE RESEARCH, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AND INNOVATIVE PROJECTS, OR SPONSORSHIPS THAT ARE NOT ADDRESSED THROUGH NOAA'S COMPETITIVE DISCRETIONARY PROGRAMS.  THIS REQUEST DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE NOAA'S LONG-TERM MISSION GOAL #3: HEALTHY OCEANS AS WELL AS LONG-TERM MISSION GOAL #4: RESILIENT COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIES. THIS REQUEST ALSO ADDRESSES NOAA RESTORE SCIENCE PROGRAM'S GOAL TO SUPPORT THE SCIENCE AND COORDINATION NECESSARY FOR BETTER UNDERSTANDING AND MANAGEMENT OF THE GULF OF MEXICO ECOSYSTEM.  THE GULF OF MEXICO CONFERENCE (AKA "GOMCON") IS A COMBINATION OF THREE MAJOR CONFERENCES THAT HAPPEN ON A REGULAR BASIS IN THE GULF REGION: THE ANNUAL GULF OF MEXICO ALLIANCE ALL HANDS MEETING, THE ANNUAL GULF OF MEXICO OIL SPILL AND ECOSYSTEM SCIENCE (GOMOSES) MEETING, AND THE STATE OF THE GULF SUMMIT HOSTED TRIENNIALLY BY HARTE RESEARCH INSTITUTE. BY COMBINING ALL THREE, GOMCON ENCOURAGES RESE

THE NORTH INLET  WINYAH BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (NI-WB NERR) IS ADMINISTERED BY THE BELLE W. BARUCH INSTITUTE FOR MARINE AND COASTAL SCIENCES, UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA, WHICH IS SUBMITTING THIS APPLICATION FOR FY 2021 FUNDS TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CCVATCH CLIMATEVULNERABILITY.APP, AN ONLINE TOOL TO FACILITATE HABITAT VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS. THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA IS REQUESTING $68,970 FROM THE NOS OFFICE FOR COASTAL MANAGEMENT FOR THIS TASK, WHICH IS INTENDED FOR CFDA NUMBER 11.420 (THE NERRS OPERATIONS FUNDING). BECAUSE THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE ENTIRE RESERVE SYSTEM, THERE IS NO MATCH REQUIRED.
MARINE BOARD GENERAL PROGRAM SUPPORT 2021-2022

THE COASTAL RESPONSE RESEARCH CENTER (CRRC) IS A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN NOAA'S OFFICE OF RESPONSE AND RESTORATION (OR&R), AND THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE (UNH). THE GOAL OF THE CENTER IS TO REDUCE THE CONSEQUENCES OF SPILLS AND OTHER HAZARDS THAT THREATEN COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS AND COMMUNITIES BY CONDUCTING RESEARCH, DEVELOPING NEW RESPONSE AND RESTORATION METHODS, AND TRANSFERRING TECHNOLOGY TO PRACTITIONERS. THE CENTER FOCUSES ON THE EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND TECHNOLOGY INVOLVED WITH ALL ASPECTS OF SPILLS AND HAZARDS. THE OVERALL OBJECTIVES OF THE CRRC ARE DEVELOPING NEW APPROACHES TO RESPONSE AND RESTORATION THROUGH RESEARCH/SYNTHESIS OF INFORMATION, SERVING AS A RESOURCE FOR OR&R AND NOAA AND A HUB FOR BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH AND OUTREACH ON RESPONSE AND RESTORATION TO NATURAL AND HUMAN-CAUSED DISASTERS. THE CENTER TRANSFORMS RESEARCH RESULTS INTO PRACTICE AND EDUCATES/TRAINS STUDENTS WHO WILL PURSUE CAREERS IN RESPONSE AND RESTORATION. CRRC ADDRESSES NOAA'S LONG-TERM GOAL
WHITE ABALONE RESTORATION CO-CULTURE RESEARCH AND PRODUCTION
